items.message: River levels remain high and have started to rise again at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland may re-occur this afternoon, Friday 07/01/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. At 9:30am today, Friday 07/01/22 the level at the Cae Howel gauge was 3.2m and rising. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and river levels are forecast to rise as a result. We are closely monitoring the situation. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.3 to 3.7m Saturday evening 08/01/22; Cae Howel 4 to 4.4m Sunday morning, 09/01/22. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible overnight tonight into the morning Saturday 8th January. High water levels may last over the weekend with a reaction to forecast rain interacting with tides and natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Saturday 8th January.
This flood alert has been removed as conditions have eased and tides have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold at Islip. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast today, 07/01/22. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary, with further rainfall over the weekend.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads is possible from 5am on Saturday.

Heavy rain is forecast across Mid and East Devon over Friday night into Saturday morning. This is expected to cause river levels in the River Clyst and Culm catchments to rise.

We expect flooding to affect  Cullompton, Willand, Culmstock, Hemyock, Bradninch, Broadclyst, Clyst St Mary.
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
River levels will remain high throughout the weekend as further heavy showers are forecast, please take care near the areas of concern.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the early hours of tomorrow morning, 08/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Further persistent rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to begin rising around 01:00 on 08/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Saturday, 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further rainfall is forecast today, 07/01/22. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary, with further rainfall over the weekend.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistant rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin tomorrow morning, 08/01/22.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to begin rising in the early hours of tomorrow morning on 08/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 08/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Bristol Avon due to today's rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow morning which is expected to cause river levels to rise further at the Bradford-on-Avon and Semmington guages. .
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on the morning of Saturday 8th January.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and a small tidal surge.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.68mAOD at 18:00 today, Friday 7th January 2022. (mAOD is metres above ordnance datum, or height above average level).

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 95 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 this evening.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible overnight tonight into the morning, Saturday 8th January. High water levels may last over the weekend with a reaction to forecast rain interacting with tides and natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Saturday 8th January.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There is the potential for levels to rise again over the weekend with a combination of tides and rainfall. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
    
We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message:

Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
River levels will remain high throughout the weekend as further heavy showers are forecast, please take care near the areas of concern.
